subject: communication
question_text: Think of a time when you have been moved to change your thinking about a topic. Maybe it was hearing about child labor in sweatshops that produce products from your favorite store, or learning about racial segregation in school districts, or becoming educated about the tons of food that goes to waste across the country each year. In the following response, write 3–4 thoughtful and detailed sentences about what moved you to change your thinking or position on a topic. Was the message delivered in-person or mediated? What was in the content of the message that you found moving? Who sent the message? What about the messenger made you not only listen, but be moved to change? In general, are you someone who is more motivated to change because you have had an emotional response, logical one, or a combination of both?

file_name: What is the process of sketching a graph of secant or cosecant?..md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What is the process of sketching a graph of secant or cosecant?.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: What is the process of sketching a graph of secant or cosecant?
answer_text:
First sketch out a graph of the equivalent cos/sin function.

draw vertical asymptotes at the interval of the period, starting at the origin + 1/2 * period. (if period is 2π then an asymptote will be at intervals of 2π started at -π and π accordingly.)

draw parabolic x^2 function originating from each peak or valley

file_name: What are strategies for speaking where difficult language makes an idea hard for your audience to understand? How do you effectively overcome this barrier?..md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What are strategies for speaking where difficult language makes an idea hard for your audience to understand? How do you effectively overcome this barrier?.md
subject: communication
question_text: What are strategies for speaking where difficult language makes an idea hard for your audience to understand? How do you effectively overcome this barrier? explain four things you can do:
answer_text:
1. Provide a common exemplar, or an ideal example of the concept.
2. Provide a definition that explains the essential characteristics of the concept.
3. Share several examples and nonexamples of the concept to help distinguish between what the concept is and what it is not.
4. Give your audience an opportunity to practice identifying examples and non examples of the concept. (Participation)

file_name: What is the difference between a denotative definition and a connotative definition?..md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What is the difference between a denotative definition and a connotative definition?.md
subject: communication
question_text: What is the difference between a denotative definition and a connotative definition?
answer_text: The denotative definition is the dictionary definition, or the literal definition that explains how the word is used in formal contexts. The connotative definition of a word includes an explanation of how the word is used in contemporary contexts, informal or colloquial talk, along with emotional responses attached to the word.

file_name: What are the three primary reasons that ideas can be difficult to understand?..md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What are the three primary reasons that ideas can be difficult to understand?.md
subject: communication
question_text: What are the three primary reasons that ideas can be difficult to understand?
answer_text:
1. Difficult Language (the language or concepts are difficult)
2. Difficult to Picture (the structure or process is hard to envision)
3. Difficult to believe (the idea is difficult to believe)

file_name: What are four steps to take when speaking on an idea that is difficult to believe?..md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What are four steps to take when speaking on an idea that is difficult to believe?.md
subject: communication
question_text: What are four steps to take when speaking on an idea that is difficult to believe?
answer_text:
1. Acknowledge - your audiences everyday undestanding, or "lay" theory, of how the phenomenon works. Consider asking your audience to describe the concept in their own words to better understand their perspective
2. Acknowledge - Why that explanation seems plausible on the surface
3. Explain - why that impression is incorrect or incomplete, show examples that demonstrate why it is not adequate.
4. Explain - the concept or theory more completely and illustrate why it is effective.

file_name: What was John Locke's goal in his essay on humane understanding?..md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What was John Locke's goal in his essay on humane understanding?.md
subject: philosophy
question_text: What was John Locke's goal in his essay on humane understanding?
answer_text:
Locke's Goal: A reasonable account of everyday human understanding. Not absolute certainty	

Quotes: "our business here is not to know all things, but those which concern our conduct."	"Humans have light enough to lead them."..."reason shines bright enough for all our purposes"	"If we will disbelieve everything, because we cannot certainly know all things, we shall do much-what as wisely as he who would not use his legs, but sit still and perish, because he has no wings to fly."

subject: philosophy
question_text: What was John Locke's response to the Universal Agreement argument?
answer_text:
P2: There is no universal agreement. ex. children, "idiots" (i.2.5)
P1: Universal agreement does not imply innateness (i.2.18-19, i.2.28)

file_name: What is the Universal Agreement argument?..md
subject: philosophy
question_text: What is the Universal Agreement argument?
answer_text:
P1: If an idea is universally agreed upon, then it must be innate.
P2: Some ideas are universally agreed upon.
C: Some ideas are innate

file_name: What is John Locke's response to the dormant ideas argument?..md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What is John Locke's response to the dormant ideas argument?.md
subject: philosophy
question_text: What is John Locke's response to the dormant ideas argument?
answer_text:
P1: Thoughts are conscious, or there are not thoughts at all (I.2.5)
P2: Reduction to Absurdity: If true, then every idea can be said to be innate. (I.2.8, 18)
P2: That is an explanatory circle that amounts to a contradiction (I.2.9)

file_name: What is the Dormant Ideas Argument?..md
subject: philosophy
question_text: What is the Dormant Ideas Argument?
answer_text:
P1: Some propositions exist that appear as self-evident when we focus on them and even if we were not aware of them before.
P2: That such propositions appear to be self-evident if we focus on them is a sufficient proof that they are dormant, innate ideas.
C: There exists dormant, innate ideas in our understanding

question_text: In Social Judgement Theory, there are four terms that make up the theory. What are they and explain what they mean.
answer_text:
Judgmental anchor refers to the person's current position on an issue.

latitude of acceptance: refers to positions your audience is already willing to agree with or support.

latitude of noncommitment: refers to positions your audience feels neutral or indifferent about

latitude of rejection: refers to positions your audience finds objectionable, and not willing to accept.
